summary: some of the worst haemorrhagic fever outbreaks in humans, great apes and nonhuman primates have been caused by Ebola viruses (EBOV) and Marburg virus (MARV) these enveloped filamentous single-stranded RNA viruses belong to the family Filoviridae. the only EBOV species found outside of africa is Reston ebolavirus (REBOV) experimental ZEBOV and REBOV in pigs seem to target the respiratory system but only the former induces overt clinical disease [5], [6]. pigs could transmit virus to contact animals. the aim of the current report was to further elucidate the mechanisms involved in the cellular infiltration into the lungs. we aimed to characterize the cellular infiltrates into the lungs using cell type-specific surface markers, also permitting the definitive identification of the cells harbouring ZEBOV antigen. two pigs were euthanized at 3, 5 and 7 days post inoculation. tissues collected for virus isolation and pathology. six pigs of same age group and source as in experiment 1 were acclimatized and inoculated. Enteroviral armoured RNA (Asuragen, Austin, Tx., U.S.A.) was used as an exogenous extraction/reaction control. a standard curve generated by serial 10 fold dilutions of EBOV L-gene plasmid was included for every run.
